verses.text: Give thanks to the LORD, for He is good; His steadfast love endures forever.
verses.comment: The refrain of thanksgiving found in several psalms. The Hebrew 'hesed' means covenantal love, with enduring faithfulness.

verses.text: Let Israel now say, "His steadfast love endures forever."
verses.comment: The covenant people are called to proclaim God's enduring love. The recurring refrain emphasizes the communal profession of faith.

verses.text: Let the house of Aaron now say, "His steadfast love endures forever."
verses.comment: The priestly line (Aaron's house) is specifically called to proclaim God's mercy, showing the importance of priestly intercession in worship.

verses.text: Let those who fear the LORD now say, "His steadfast love endures forever."
verses.comment: Gentiles and converts are included here ('those who fear the LORD'), expressing the universal reach of God's mercy.

verses.text: Out of my distress I called on the LORD; the LORD answered me and set me in a broad place.
verses.comment: A broad place symbolizes salvation and freedom after trouble—a theme echoed in salvation history.

verses.text: The LORD is on my side; I will not fear. What can man do to me?
verses.comment: Quoted in Hebrews 13:6, this verse highlights trust in God's sovereignty above all earthly threats.

verses.text: The LORD is with me as my helper; I will look in triumph upon my enemies.
verses.comment: The psalmist’s confidence mirrors divine support for the faithful, hinted at later in Christ, who conquers opposition.

verses.text: It is better to take refuge in the LORD than to trust in man.
verses.comment: Traditional wisdom literature, contrasted with self-reliance. Trust in God anchors all spiritual security.

verses.text: It is better to take refuge in the LORD than to trust in princes.
verses.comment: Political power is subordinate to divine providence—a recurring theme in the psalms.

verses.text: All nations surrounded me; in the name of the LORD I cut them off.
verses.comment: An individual (or Israel) speaks of being beset by enemies but finding victory through God alone.

verses.text: They surrounded me, surrounded me on every side; in the name of the LORD I cut them off.
verses.comment: Repetition here echoes the severity of trials and the certainty of God's deliverance.

verses.text: They surrounded me like bees; they blazed like fire among thorns; in the name of the LORD I cut them off.
verses.comment: The bee image conveys swarming foes; fire among thorns emphasizes intense, but short-lived, attacks.

verses.text: I was pushed hard, so that I was falling, but the LORD helped me.
verses.comment: The psalmist’s helpless state is answered only by God’s intervention, prefiguring Christ’s sufferings and vindication (see Isa. 53:4–6).

verses.text: The LORD is my strength and my song; He has become my salvation.
verses.comment: Direct allusion to the Song of Moses (Exodus 15:2). This line is strong in worship traditions and prefigures the Messiah as Savior.

verses.text: Shouts of joy and salvation are in the tents of the righteous: "The right hand of the LORD does valiantly,"
verses.comment: "Right hand" signifies divine power in action, a theme continuing into the New Testament (Acts 2:33, Mark 16:19).

verses.text: "The right hand of the LORD is exalted; the right hand of the LORD does valiantly!"
verses.comment: Verse 16 expands the triumph of the LORD, reinforcing His supreme might in the psalmist’s praise.

verses.text: I shall not die, but live, and declare the works of the LORD.
verses.comment: The theme of life restored anticipates resurrection and Christian witness (see John 11:25).

verses.text: The LORD has disciplined me severely, but He has not given me over to death.
verses.comment: God’s discipline is loving correction, not condemnation. See Hebrews 12:6 for the loving discipline of God's children.

verses.text: Open to me the gates of righteousness, that I may enter through them and give thanks to the LORD.
verses.comment: This image points toward entering God's presence, later given new meaning in Jesus (John 10:9; Heb. 10:20).

verses.text: This is the gate of the LORD; the righteous shall enter through it.
verses.comment: Spiritual and literal meaning—holy access to God, first in the temple, fulfilled finally in Christ.

verses.text: I thank you that you have answered me and have become my salvation.
verses.comment: God, the answerer of prayer, becomes 'salvation'—a title later given to Christ (Matthew 1:21; Luke 2:30).

verses.text: The stone the builders rejected has become the cornerstone.
verses.comment: This messianic prophecy is fulfilled in Jesus’ rejection and exaltation. Jesus applies this directly to Himself (see Matt. 21:42, Acts 4:11), showing divine selection despite human judgment.

verses.text: This is the LORD’s doing; it is marvelous in our eyes.
verses.comment: God sovereignly chooses and exalts—His ways surpass human expectations, prefiguring the paradox of Christ’s cross and resurrection.

verses.text: This is the day that the LORD has made; let us rejoice and be glad in it.
verses.comment: More than a general day, this points to the great day of salvation, ultimately fulfilled in Christ's resurrection.

verses.text: Save us, we pray, O LORD! O LORD, we pray, give us success!
verses.comment: ‘Hosanna’ used at Jesus’ entry into Jerusalem (Matt. 21:9). A prayer for salvation that becomes acclamation for the Messiah.

verses.text: Blessed is he who comes in the name of the LORD! We bless you from the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: Directly applied to Jesus at His triumphal entry. The ‘house of the LORD’ alludes to worship centered in God's presence.

verses.text: The LORD is God, and He has made His light shine upon us. Bind the festal sacrifice with cords up to the horns of the altar.
verses.comment: Festal sacrifice points to worship and the sacrificial system—fulfilled spiritually in Christ’s offering on the cross (Heb. 9:26).

verses.text: You are my God, and I will give you thanks; you are my God; I will exalt you.
verses.comment: The climax of personal praise, affirming exclusive devotion to the Lord—a picture of the soul's union with God, fostered through praise and worship.

verses.text: Give thanks to the LORD, for He is good; His steadfast love endures forever.
verses.comment: The psalm ends with the anthem of God's eternal mercy—recurring among the faithful and fulfilled in Christ's eternal priesthood (see Heb. 7:24–25).
